commit.message: Release 0.3.0

Update tested versions on Travis

Python 2.6 and Python 3.3 are not supported by Travis anymore at all. Instead
test Python 3.7 and 3.8.

Only do tests on specific Python versions

Multiple starargs/kwargs only work since Python 3.5

Fixing typo

Fixing typo

Allow starargs not only at the end

With Python 3.5 the number and location of starargs (as well as the kwargs)
was relaxed. With 2b0b21c this was implemented but "required" the starargs to
be at the end. In the end most checks are disabled when starargs are used, so
the location shouldn't really matter, relaxing the condition.
Additionally it supports now any number of starargs.

Re-add Python 3.6 tests

Update the Python versions on which the tests are run. Previously the
"nightly" tests would use Python 3.6, but now it is Python 3.7. So it is
explicitly using Python 3.6 and change 3.5-dev to the released version.

Remove reordering in test

Remove reordering the output in Flake8 version 3, as it should be fixed in
future versions. Travis will install a version which is at least 3.0.3 and on
local tests it should also use at least that version (or use version 2).

Switch Flake8 version

The default Flake8 version should be the newest, as it seems matured. It also
changes Python 2.6 and 3.3 to only run on Flake8 before version 3 as it
dropped support (and won't run on Python 2.6 anymore).
Add Flake8 framework classifier

Remove standalone functionality

Using this script standalone is problematic when using the new Flake8 3.x
options which will be introduced in this version.

Do tests with Flake8

As this is a plugin of Flake8 it should also test it using Flake8. There is a
workaround for Flake8 3.x because it sometimes does change the order it
reports the errors. So this is sorting them on Flake8.

Do not skip Python 2.6 problems

In the dynamic code generator, a P10* error is always a P301 error in Python
2.6, so it could expect as such.

Improve error message comparison

The error message comparison tests were using basic assertions and both
iterating over iterators. So it was only showing the first error and didn't
really compare both entries. It could also only report the first difference.

It now compares all reports with the expected reports and prints the
difference. Additionally it checks through the reports that are missing and
tries to find exactly one unexpected report which has only one different
attribute (like the line number) and will actually tell that it expected the
other values. That report won't show up as unexpected but instead together
with the missing one in that list.
Release 0.2.3

Disallow failure of Python 2.6 builds again

The Python 2.6 build was allowed to fail, because it couldn't detect format
strings which use implicit parameters. It cannot just ignore P101-P103 results
as it'll also detect unused parameters (as P301) because it didn't detect that
it would be used on Python 2.7 and up.

So it just skips the tests which would usually fail.

Support multiple errors per line in tests

If a line in a test file issues multiple errors, they should all be checked.
This changes the layout a little.

Improve and fix typos in README

Use the uppercase variant Flake8 as well as link to it and not use it as code.
Also explicitly mention support for Flake8 3.x.

Fix entry point name

The entry point previously used the plugin name as its name, which actually
breaks in Flake8 3.x as it won't automatically select this plugin. By using
the error code space as the name it'll be automatically selected.
Release 0.2.2

Support str.format in manual tests

Defining that the next line an error is expected also requires defining the
indentation. The indentation can be guessed but it didn't actually included
`str.format` in the possible guesses.

Fix col_offset in Python 3.4.2

Due to https://bugs.python.org/issue21295 the col_offset value in Python 3.4.2
might not be pointing to the actual start of the problematic call, so it needs
to be manually fixed.

Implement generic way to test custom cases

At the moment all tests used a dynamically created list of lines, but that
technique is limited to test some edge cases. To handle them it is possible to
write code manually which is then parsed and handled by the test.

Do not skip all Expr

With 156fb2c9 it did skip all `Expr`, but it must still handle the calls inside
them.

Properly assert that varargs are at the end (#11)

With version 3.5 the varargs are now part of the normal argument list and thus
it is not guaranteed that they are at the end. But that is required for the
rest of the code to actually do the right thing, so it asserted that but did it
incorrectly.

Simplify kwargs detection

The keywords which have been already handled should contain a `None` entry, if
the function call uses kwargs. So it can just do a simple `contains` check.

Reuse temporary file

Instead of creating the temporary file for each separate test, it could just
reuse it and call it with different ignored codes and positions.

Store dynamic code and expected errors

Instead of calling it several times, just create it once and reuse it every
time. It also removes `TestCaseBase.run_test` as it is nowhere used.

Document a bit of the dynamic code generator

The code generator for the test has some magic formats, explain them better to
make it easier to understand what is happening.

[IMPROV] Don't check expressions which aren't docstrings

Only actual docstrings can be accessed via `__doc__` but strings (also when
they use triple quotes) cannot be accessed later so it's not sensible to check
them for format.
[IMPROV] Calculate offset dynamically
